I would like to see a somewhat shorter day* since I left with an exhausted feeling
after the 8:00 AM to 9:30 plus, sessions* The term, "workshop,1' was overrating what
actually happened? If the seme format is to he used in the future, the tern "confer®
ance," might be more applicable„ I believe that if personnel attending future "work®
shops" are of the same level of operational experience that in many cases, the work¬
shop technique would be of more use* The only place that I could see this technique
used at this yearns workshop, was the method used for only one demonsl,ration—that
of Kine® recorder ope ration? If one were to have a four unit demonstration with the
participants split into four groups, on an experience level basis, with much more
activity on the individuals part, I believe that the possibility of passing on more
experienced "know-how^ could be achieved* This would put a considerable load on the
individual responsible for a demonstration* He would be required to repeat the same
basic information to each group, plus trying to give those of different experience
levels, the needed advanced material* Beyond that, this method would require at least
the number of separate work spaces as there are groups* Perhaps a compromise could
be worked out with only two units, on a rotation basis| rather than four units*
Although there was a wealth of material on the operational technique of lighting,
K±ne®operation, and some on theory of the same, too little was devoted to test pro®
cedures that would enable one to attain the standards that are hoped for in the
NAEB* The two people who gave significant contributions to this, were Jack Chenoweth
and Fred Remley, although some was made by George Howard, from General Electric, with
his light meters* More in this line would have been greatly appreciated* It may be
felt that this type of information should be a basic requirement for personnel in
this field, but many of us have entered via other routes and do not have what I
would call a working knowledge of common testing techniques used in the industry*
This workshop has given me a much better insight into the film recording business than
I had before* Greatly appreciated, was the information given by Mr* Kelly, of J* Ac
Maurer Co«, although it was not of a very technical nature* Never having been ex®
posed to anything like large scale film processing, the trip to the small processing
plant was enjoyed* It gave me a better understanding of the standardization of proc®
easing, as explained by W* H* Smith of Lakeside Laboratory* Paul Ireland*s pertinent
remarks were also enjoyed*
A note should be added in appreciation of the excellent talk by Prof* Stasheff, of the
University of Michigan* His speech was by far, the most tension relieving*
From a humorous aspect and also providing some very useful information to one not fam¬
iliar with microwave technique, was the talk of Alan MacIntyre, of WUNC-TV* It was
well backed with factual information by Mr? McLaughlin, of Raytheon*
The wealth of other information available through talks and that gathered via the
"bull sessions," was enlightening, and although I feel that I personally contributed
little to the conference, other than my presence, I hope to see the expansion of the
workshop in the future as a method to educate the educators in all phases of the NAEB
program*
I wish to take ray hat off to Mr* Cecil Bidlack, for a commendable jobs
